snippet: President Obama is expected to sign the bill, which would restore authority for school performance and accountability to districts and states after a long period of federal control.
abstract: Senate votes 85 to 12 to approve large-scale changes to No Child Left Behind law, in proposal that could effectively end controversial federal policy that has governed education for more than decade; changes, expected to gain approval from Pres Obama, would restore much control to local districts and states.

byline.contributor: Motoko Rich contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: President Obama is expected to sign the bill, which would restore authority for school performance and accountability to districts and states after a long period of federal control.

headline.main: Senate Approves Overhaul of No Child Left Behind Law
headline.print_headline: Education Law Changes Approved by the Senate
